awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of a Scanning Electron Microscope for Research and Training at Millersville University
awd_abstract_narration:
This award from the Major Research Instrumentation program supports the acquisition of a Scanning Electron Microscope (SEM) at Millersville University. This research tool enables activities that strengthen the research and teaching abilities at the institution. Millersville University is a public, primarily undergraduate university. In addition, there are many stakeholders interested in accessing the instrument. Developing the next generation of engineers and scientists is paramount to the prosperity of the nation by maintaining our competitive edge in the development of technology and intellectual capital. Providing meaningful experiences at all levels of academia is central to recruiting and retaining talented students in science and engineering. The project connects various aspects of education and community outreach using the SEM.  This project has been coordinated with faculty at nearby Franklin and Marshall College and includes support from local industry, K-12 institutions, and community outreach groups. By offering access to this equipment and providing assistance in using it, the investigators strengthen the ties within this local network, advance scientific inquiry and discovery, support the local economy through business development, develop new pathways for youth to learn about science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM) disciplines, and draw more students to pursue careers in these areas. Because there is a lack of access, a strong demand, and a detailed plan for implementing these activities at various levels within the local community, it is anticipated that the impact will be felt deeply across the region, and it will result in the advancement of STEM education and opportunities in the area.
 
This award to Millersville University (MU)supports the acquisition of tungsten-filament SEM with energy-dispersive x-ray spectroscopy capability and provides critical capability in sample analysis and support on-going research projects in materials science, biology, geology, and chemistry, and more. Specific research projects include research in (1) new solid-state metal foams; (2) far from equilibrium processing of novel materials;(3) synthesis of nanoparticles of different shapes and sizes for comparative studies on catalysis; 4) forensic, and systematic botany. MU will provide technical support for the SEM for the expanding research on campus, as well as attracting industrial partners. Outreach and learning activities serve 22 school districts and other educational centers in the area, and the School District of Lancaster, which is comprised of 87% minority students. Outreach activities are planned through the North Museum of Science and the Lancaster Science Factory. Furthermore, K-12 students activities include campus visit during a variety of STEM-related competitions and events, such as the Science Olympiad and the Made in Millersville student research conference. The project also includes service to the broader academic community by joining the Remote Access Instrumentation Network in partnership with Penn State's Center for Nanotechnology Education and Utilization.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The successful acquisition and installation of a Hitachi SU3900 Scanning Electron Microscope (SEM) was completed in January and February of 2021. Any delays were due to the COVID-19 pandemic.

 A new location in the Science Complex at Millersville University (MU) was identified as a suitable location for the SEM installation and some renovations were necessary for its optimal operation. The renovations and facility furbishing cost exceeded the amount of $155,000 (design, construction, supporting equipment, furniture). The money for the renovations as well as funds to purchase supporting equipment and furniture for the facility was provided by MU. The room renovations were completed in December 2020. 

A part-time SEM technician/biology technician position was developed. The advertisement and search to fill this position was done during the Fall of 2021. The position was filled in January 2022.

For the continuous maintenance and operation of the new SEM, a three (3) year service contract for the instrument was acquired during purchase in addition to the purchase of basic and advanced trainings for new users.

From January to June 2021, basic training of new users was performed by Hitachi/Oxford engineers. Five (5) training sessions were offered during January, February, and June of 2021 using different modalities due to the pandemic. A total of eighteen (18) MU faculty and staff and one (1) staff from a surrounding institution received basic training.

Advanced trainings of new users wer performed in August of 2021 and June of 2022 by Hitachi and Oxford application engineers, respectively. Those sessions were all done in person. Two 2-day trainings were done on the SEM and the EDS X-ray hardware and software. A total of seven (7) MU faculty and staff participated.

(MU provided $5020 in funds to have an on-site advanced training from Oxford Instruments).

Two (2) MU undergraduate research students used the SEM for research and received basic training from the PI in the Fall of 2021.

More basic trainings were provided by the SEM technician to eleven (11) MU students in the senior Analytical Chemistry class, and one (1) local industry user.

 A total of ten (10) MU faculty and staff received advanced training from Hitachi and Oxford engineers from August 2021 to June 2022 and a total of twenty (20) MU faculty, staff, and students received basic training as well as one (1) local industry user.

 All training sessions were video recorded and were made available to users through an online private platform.

The SEM technician was introduced to all MU science departments and the SEM services were made available. An SEM website was also developed: (https://www.millersville.edu/emlab/) which includes information about the SEM facility, supporting instrumentation, hourly fees, as well as contact and shipping information. An educational poster was created and posted in at least two key locations of the science complex. The MU communication department is in preparation of a featured article dedicated to the microscope that will be released later in the Summer of 2022 or Fall 2022. Academic institutions, local industry/companies and local K-12 schools have been contacted to promote the use of the SEM microscope.

The SEM was used in research projects, in training activities for MU faculty & students through coursework, and for demonstrations and training/work of external users.

 Research:

a)     In the Fall of 2021, the microscope was used by two (2) MU undergraduate chemistry students for characterization of Zinc Oxide and Copper Oxide/Copper Hydroxide nanostructures, respectively. One student received and internal grant (Fall 2021) to support his research and the other student presented his work during a senior Chemistry seminar, Spring 2022.

b)     The SEM technician worked with two MU chemistry faculty and assisted with the investigation of the composition of a newly synthesized Iridium organometallic catalyst and newly formed Gold-Palladium nanowires.

Coursework at MU:

The SEM technician was able to provide basic training and demonstrate the operation of the microscope and promote awareness of its uses to:

a) eleven (11) MU students from the Analytical Chemistry course

b) twelve (12)   MU students from the Honors Seminar in Introductory Chemistry course

c) sixteen (16) MU students from the Microbiology course

Demonstrations and training of external users:

The SEM technician worked with different external users to:

a)  demonstrate the operation of the microscope and promote awareness of its uses to fifteen (15) high-school students, from surrounding PA and MD area high schools, participating in the Student Science Training Program (S.S.T.P.) offered annually by the College of Science and Technology at Millersville University.

b)  demonstrate the operation of the microscope and the EDS X-ray detector as well as assist a senior Analytical Chemist with the composition of samples from Adhesives Research, Glen Rock, PA.

c)    collaborate and run biological samples of isopods and new copepod species samples for the Department of Marine Sciences at the University of Puerto Rico, Mayaguez.
